data.text: Any of numerous cold-blooded aquatic vertebrates characteristically having fins, gills, and a streamlined body and including the bony fishes, such as catfishes and tunas, and the cartilaginous fishes, such as sharks and rays.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various jawless aquatic craniates, including the lampreys and hagfishes.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The flesh of such animals used as food.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A person, especially one considered deficient in something.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To catch or try to catch fish.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To look for something by feeling one's way; grope.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: fished in both pockets for a coin.

data.text: To seek something in a sly or indirect way.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To catch or try to catch (fish).
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To catch or try to catch fish in.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
